kill them with a frown, to strike them dead with a sharpe eye,
to make you this day wear a feather, and tomorrow a sick
night-cap: O, why this is rare, there is a certain deity in
this, when a Lady by the Magic of her looks, can turn
a man into twenty shapes.

sp.speaker: Orle.
sp.p: Sweet friend, she speaks this but to torture me.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: I will teach thee how to plague her: love her not.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p:
Poor Orleans, how lamentably he looks: if he
stay, he will make me surely love him for pure pity. I must
send him hence, for of all sorts of love. I hate the French:
I pray thee, sweet prisoner, entreat Lord Longauile to
come to me presently.

sp.speaker: Orle.
sp.p:
I will: and esteem myself more than happy,
that you will employ me.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p:
Watch him, watch him for Gods sake, if he sigh
not or look not back.

sp.speaker: Cyp.
sp.p: He does both: but what mystery lies in this?

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p:
Nay, no mystery, it is as plain as Cupids forehead:
why this is as it should be: And esteem myself
more than happy, that you will employ me: my French
prisoner is in love over head and ears.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.p: it is wonder how he scapes drowning.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: With whom think you?

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p:
With his keeper, for a good wager: Ah, how glad
is he to obey? And how proud am I to command in this Empire
of affection? Over him and such Spongy-livered youths,
(that lie soaking in love) I triumph more with mine eye,
than ever he did over a Soldier with his sword. Is it not a
gallant victory for me to subdue my Fathers enemy with a
look? Prince of Cyprus, you were best take heed, how
you encounter an English Lady.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.p: God bless me from loving any of you, if all be so cruel.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p:
God bless me from suffering you to love me, if
you be not so formable.

sp.speaker: Cyp.
sp.p: Will you command me any service, as you have done Orleans:

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p:
No other service but this, that (as Orleans) you
love me, for no other reason, but that I may torment you.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.p:
I will: conditionally, that in all company I may
call you my tormentor.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.p:
You shall: conditionally, that you never beg for mercy.
Come, my Lord of Galloway.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Come, sweet Madam.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: The Ruby-coloured portals of her speech
Were closed by mercy: but upon her eye,
(Attired in frowns) sat murdering cruelty.
She is angry, that I durst so high aspire.
O, she disdains that any strangers breast
Should be a Temple for her deity:
She is full of beauty, full of bitterness.
Till now, I did not dally with loves fire:
And when I thought to try his flames indeed,
I burnt me even to cinders: O, my stars,
Why from my native shore did your beams guide me,
To make me dote on her that doth deride me?

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.p:
Hold him in this mind, sweet Cupid, I conjure thee.
O, what music these hey-hoes make? I was about to cast my
little little self into a great love trance for him, fearing his heart
had been flint: but since I see it is pure virgin wax, he shall melt
his belly full: for now I know how to temper him.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: Never beg mercy? yet be my tormentor.
I hope she heard me not: doubtless she did:
And now will she insult upon my passions,
And vex my constant love with mockeries.
Nay, then I will be mine own Physician,
And out face love, and make her think that I
Mourned thus, because I saw her standing by.
What news, my Lord of Cornewall?

sp.speaker: Cornew.
sp.l: This fair Prince,
One of your Countrymen, is come to Court,
A lusty gallant brave in Cyprus Isle,
With fifty bard Horses prancing at his heels,
Backed by as many strong limbed Cypriots.
All whom he keeps in pay: whose offered service,
Our king with Arms of gladness hath embraced.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: Born in the Isle of Cyprus? what is his name?

sp.speaker: Cornw.
sp.l: His servants call him Fortunatus son.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: Rich Fortunatus son? Is he arrived?

div1.stage: Enter Longauile, Galloway, and Chester with Iewels.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: This he bestowed on me.

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: And this on me.

sp.speaker: Gallow.
sp.l: And this bounteous hand enforced me take.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: I prize this Jewel at a hundred Marks,
Yet would he needs bestow this gift on me.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: My Lords, whose hand hath been thus prodigal?

sp.speaker: Gallow.
sp.l: Your countrymen my Lord, a Cypriot.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: The gallant sure is all compact of gold,
To every Lady hath he given rich Jewels,
And sent to every servant in the Court
Twenty fair English Angels.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: This is rare.

sp.speaker: Lincol.
sp.l: My Lords, prepare yourselves for revelling,
It is the kings pleasure that this day be spent
In royal pastimes, that this golden Lord,
(For so all that behold him, christen him)
May taste the pleasures of our English court.
Here comes the gallant, shining like the Sun.

div1.stage: Trumpets sound: Enter Athelstane, Andelocia, Agripyne, Orleans, Ladies, and other attendants, Insultado a Spanish Lord: Musicke sounds within.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: For these your royal favours done to me,
(Being a poor stranger) my best powers shall prove,
By Acts of worth, the soundness of my love.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Herein your love shall best set out itself,
By staying with us: if our English Isle
Hold any object welcome to your eyes,
Do but make choice, and claim it as your prize.

div1.stage: The King and Cyprus conferre aside.

sp.speaker: Ande.
sp.l: I thank your grace: would he durst keep his word,
I know what I would claim: Tush, man, be bold,
Were she a Saint, she may be won with gold.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: It is strange I must confess, but in this pride,
His Father Fortunatus (if he live)
Consumes his life in Cyprus: still he spends,
And still his Coffers with abundance swell,
But how he gets these riches none can tell.

div1.stage: The King and Agripyne conferre aside.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Hold him in talk: come hither, Agripyne.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: But what enticed young Andelociaes soul
To wander hither?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: That which did allure,
My sovereigns son, the wonder of the place.

sp.speaker: Agr.
sp.l: This curious heap of wonders, (which an Empress
Gave him) he gave me, and by Venus hand,
The warlike Amorato needs would swear,
He left his country Cyprus for my love.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: If by the sovereign Magic of thine eye,
Thou canst enchant his looks to keep the circles
Of thy fair cheeks, be bold to try thy charms,
Feed him with hopes, and find the royal vein,
That leads this Cypriot to his golden mine.
Here is Music spent in vain, Lords, fall to dancing.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: My fair tormentor, will you lend a hand?

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Isle I will try this strangers cunning in a dance.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: My cunning is but small, yet who will not prove
To shame himself for such a Ladies love?

sp.speaker: Orle.
sp.l: These Cypriots are the devils that torture me.
He courts her, and she smiles, but I am born,
To be her beauties slave, and her loves scorn.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: I shall never have the face to ask the question twice.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: What is the reason? Cowardliness or pride?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
Neither: but it is the fashion of us Cypriots, both
men and women, to yield at first assault, and we expect others
should do the like.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p:
It is a sign, that either your women are very black, and
are glad to be sped, or your men very fond, and will take no denial.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Indeed our Ladies are not so fair as you.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p:
But your men more venturous at a breach than you,
or else they are all dastardly soldiers.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
He that fights under these sweet colours, and yet
turns coward, let him be
shot to death with the terrible arrows
of fair Ladies eyes.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.p: Nay Insultado, you must not deny us.

l.foreign: My Corocon es muy pesada, my Anima muy atormentada,

p.foreign:
No per los Cielos: La piede de
Espagnoll, no haze musica in Tierra Inglesa.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: Sweet Insultado let us see you dance.
I have heard the Spanish dance is full of state.

l.foreign: Verdad Signor: la danza spagnola, es muy alta,
Maiestica, y para Monarcas: vuestra Inglesa,

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p:
Doth my Spanish prisoner deny to dance? He
has sworn to me by the cross of his pure Toledo, to be my
servant: by that oath (my Castilian prisoner) I conjure you to
show your cunning, though all your body be not free, I am
sure your heels are at liberty.

p.foreign:
Nolo quire contra dezir: vuestra oio haze conquesto
a su prisionero: Oyes, la pauyne Hispanola, sea vuestra
musica y grauidad, y maiestad: Paie, dadime Tabacca, Toma
my capa, e my espada. Mas alta, Mas alta: Desuiaios, Desuiaios,
Companieros, Mas alta, Mas alta.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Thanks, Insultado.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: It is most excellent.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: The Spaniards dance, is as his deeds be, full of pride.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: The day grows old, and what remains unspent,
Shall be consumed in banquets, Agripyne,
Leave us a while, if Andelocia please,
Go bear our beauteous daughter company.

div1.stage: Exeunt Agrip. and Andel. and Ladies.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Fortune I thank thee: now thou smilest on me.

sp.speaker: Athe.
sp.l: This Cipriot bears a gallant princely mind.
My Lord, of what birth is your country-man?
Think not, sweet Prince, that I propound this question,
To wrong you in your love to Agripyne:
Our favours grace him to an other end.
Nor let the wings of your affection droop,
Because she seems to shun loves gentle lure.
Believe it on our word, her beauties prize
Only shall yield a conquest to your eyes. But tell me what is this Fortunatus son?

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: Of honourable blood, and more renowned
In foreign kingdoms (whither his proud spirit,
Plumed with ambitious feathers, caries him)
Than in his native Country. But last day,
The father and the sons were through their riots,
Poor and disdained of all, but now they glister,
More bright than Midas: if some damned fiend
Fed not his bags, this golden pride would end.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: His pride we will somewhat tame, and curb the head
Of his rebellious prodigality:
He hath invited us, and all our Peers,
To feast with him tomorrow, his provision,
I understand may entertain three kings.
But Lincolne, let our Subjects secretly
Be charged on pain of life that not a man
Sell any kind of Fuel to his servants.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: This policy shall clip his golden wings,
And teach his pride what it is to strive with kings.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Withdraw awhile:
None filled his hands with Gold, for we set spies,
To watch who fed his prodigality:
He hung the Marble bosom of our Court,
As thick with glistering Spangles of pure gold,
As ere the spring hath stuck the earth with flowers.
Unless he melt himself to liquid gold,
Or be some God, some devil, or can transport
A mint about him, (by enchanted power)
He cannot rain such showers: with his own hands
He threw more wealth abroad in every street,
Than could be thrust into a Chariot:
He is a Magician sure, and to some fiend,
His soul (by infernal covenants) has he sold,
Always to swim up to the chin in gold.
Be what he can be, if those doting fires,
Wherein he burns for Agripinaes love,
Want power to melt from him this endless Mine,
Then (like a slave) we will chain him in our Tower,
Where tortures shall compel his sweating hands
To cast rich heaps into our treasury.

div1.stage: Musicke sounding still: A curtaine being drawne, where Andelocia lies sleeping in Agripines lap, shee has his purse, and her selfe and another Lady tye another (like it) in the place, and then rise from him.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: I have found the sacred spring that never ebbs.
But I will not shew it your majesty,
Till you have sworn by Englands royal crown,
To let me keep it.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: By my Crown I swear,
None but fair Agripyne the Gem shall wear.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Then is this mine: see, Father, here is the fire,
Whose gilded beams still burn, this is the Sun,
That ever shines, the tree that never dies,
Here grows the Garden of Hesperides,
The out-side mocks you, makes you think it is poor,
But entering it, you find eternal store.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Art sure of this? How didst thou drive it out?

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Fear not his waking yet, I made him drink
That soporiferous Juice which was composed,
To make the Queen (my Mother) relish sleep,
When her last sickness summoned her to heaven.
He sleepes profoundly: when his amorous eyes
Had singed their wings in Cupids wanton flames,
I set him all on fire, and promised love:
In pride whereof, he drew me forth this purse,
And swore, by this he multiplied his gold.
I tried and found it true: and secretly
Commanded Music with her silver tongue,
To chime soft lullabies into his soul,
And whilst my fingers wantoned with his hair,
( To entice the sleepy Juice to charm his eyes)
In all points was there made a purse, like his,
Which counterfeit is hung in place of this.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: More than a second kingdom hast thou won.
Leave him, that when he wakes he may suspect,
Some else has robbed him, come dear Agripyne,
If this strange purse his sacred virtues hold,
We will circle England with a waste of Gold.

div1.stage: Musicke still: Enter Saddow very gallant, reading a Bill, with emptie bags in his hand singing.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p:
These English occupiers are mad Trojans: let a
man pay them never so much, they will
give him nothing but
the bag. Since my master created me steward over his fifty
men, and his one and fifty horse, I have rid over much business,
yet never was galled, I thank the destinies: Music?
O delicate warble: O these Courtiers are most sweet triumphant
creatures. Seignior, Sir: Monsieur: sweet Seignior;
this is the language of the
accomplishment: O delicious strings: these heavenly wire-drawers have
stretched my master even
out at length: yet at length he must wake: master?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Wake me not yet, my gentle Agripyne.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.l: One word Sir, for the billets, and I vanish.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: There is heaven in these times: throw the musicians
A bounteous largess of three hundred Angels.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.l: Why sir, I have but ten pound left.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Ha, Shaddow? where is the Princess Agripyne?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.l: I am not Apollo, I cannot reveal.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Was not the princess here, when thou camest in?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.l: Here was no Princess but my princely self.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: In faith?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.l: No in faith, Sir.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
Where are you hid? where stand you wantoning?
Not here? gone in faith? Have you given me the slip? well, it is but
an amorous trick and so I embrace it: my horse, Shaddow,
how fare my horse?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.l: Upon the best Oats my understeward can buy.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I mean, are they lusty, sprightly, gallant, wanton, fiery?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p:
They are as all horses are, Caterpillars to the Commonwealth,
they are ever munching: but Sir, for these billets,
and these faggots and bavins?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
'sheart what billets, what faggots? dost make me
a Woodmonger?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p:
No sweet Seignior, but you have bid the King and
his Peers to dinner, and he has commanded that no Woodmonger
sell you a stick of wood, and that no Collier shall cozen
you of your measure, but must tie up the mouth of their
Sacks, least their Coals kindle your choler.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
Is it possible? is it true, or hast thou learnt of the English
gallants to gull?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: He is a gull that would be taught by such gulls.

sp.speaker: Ande.
sp.p:
Not a stick of wood? Some child of envy has buzzed
this stratagem into the kings ear, of purpose to disgrace me:
I have invited his majesty, and though it cost me a Million, I will
feast him: Shadow, thou shalt hire a hundred or two of Carts,
with them post to all the Grocers in London, buy up all the
Cinnamon, Cloves, Nutmegs, Licorice and all other spices,
that have any strong heart, and with them make fires to prepare
our Cookery:
sp.l: Ere Fortunatus son look red with shame,
He will dress a Kings feast in a spiced flame.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p:
This device, Sir, will be some what akin to Lady
Pride, it will ask cost.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Fetch twenty Porters, I will laid all with gold.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.l: First, master, fill these bags.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
Come then, hold up how now? tricks, new crochets,
Madam Fortune? Dry as an Eel-skin? Shaddow, take thou
my Gold out.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.l: Why Sir, here is none in.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Ha, let me see: O here is a bastard cheek,
I see now it is not mine: it is counterfeit,
It is so: slave thou hast robbed thy master.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Not of a penny, I have been as true a steward.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Vengeance on thee and on thy stewardship.
Yet wherefore curse I thee? thy leaden soul
Had never power to mount up to the knowledge
Of the rich mystery closed in my purse.
O no, I will curse myself, mine eyes I will curse,
They have betrayed me, I will curse my tongue,
That hath betrayed me: I will curse Agripyne,
She hath betrayed me: Sirens cease to sing,
Your charms have taken effect, for now I see,
All your enchantments were, to cozen me.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.l: What shall I do with this ten pound, Sir?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Go buy with it a Chain and hang thyself.
Now think I on my Fathers prophecy.
Tell none (quoth he) the virtue, if you do,
Much shame, much grief, much danger follows you.
With tears I credit his divinity.
O fingers, were you upright Justices,
You would tear out mine eyes: had not they gazed
On the frail colour of a painted cheek,
None had betrayed me: henceforth I will defy
All beauty, and will call a lovely eye,
A Sun whose scorching beams burn up our joys,
Or turn them black like Ethiopians.
O women, wherefore are you born men's woe,
Why are your faces framed Angelical?
Your hearts of sponges, soft and smooth in show,
But touched, with poison they do over-flow.
Had sacred wisdom been my Fathers Fate,
He had died happy, I lived fortunate.
Shaddow, bear this to beauteous Agripyne,
With it this message, tell her, I will reprove
Her covetous sin the less, because for gold,
I see that most men's souls too cheap are sold.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Shall I buy these spices today or tomorrow?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Tomorrow? Aye, tomorrow thou shalt buy them,
Tomorrow tell the Princess I will love her,
Tomorrow tell the king, I will banquet him,
Tomorrow, Shaddow, will I give thee gold,
Tomorrow pride goes bare and lust acold.
Tomorrow will the rich man feed the poor.
And vice tomorrow virtue will adore,
Tomorrow beggars shall be crowned kings,
This No-time, morrows-time, no sweetness sings:
I pray thee hence: bear that to Agripyne.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p:
I will go hence, because you send me: but I will go weeping
hence, for grief that I must turn villain as many do,
and leave you when you are up to the ears in adversity.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: She hath robbed me, and now I will play the thief,
I will steal from hence to Cyprus, for black shame.
Here (through my riots) brands my lofty name.
I will sell this pride for help to bear me thither,
So pride and beggary shall walk together:
This world is but a School of villainy,
Therefore I will rob my brother, (not of gold,
Nor of his virtues, virtue none will steal:)
But (if I can,) I will steal his wishing Hat.
And with that, wandering round about the world,
I will search all corners to find misery,
And where she dwells, I will dwell, languish and die.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Gentles, if ever you have beheld the passions,
The combats of his soul who being a king,
By some usurping hand hath been deposed
From all his royalties: even such a soul,
Such eyes, such heart swollen big with sighs and tears,
The star-crossed son of Fortunatus wears.
The thoughts crowned him a Monarch in the morn,
Yet now he is bandied by the Seas in scorn,
From wave to wave: his golden treasures spoil
Makes him in desperate language to entreat,
The winds to spend their fury on his life:
But they (being mild in tyranny) or scorning
To triumph in a wretches funeral,
Toss him to Cyprus. O what treachery
Cannot this Serpent gold entice us to?
He robs his brother of the Souldans prize,
And having got his wish (the wishing Hat)
He does not (as he vowed) seek misery,
But hopes by that to win his purse again,
And in that Hope from Cyprus is he fled.
If your swift thoughts clap on their wonted wings,
In Genoway may you take this fugitive,
Where having cozened many Jewellers,
To England back he comes, step but to court,
And there (disguised) you find him bargaining
For Jewels with the beauteous Agripyne,
Who wearing at her side the virtuous purse,
He clasps her in his arms, and as a Raven,
Griping the tender-hearted Nightingale,
So flies he with her, (wishing) in the air,
To be transported to some wilderness:
Imagine this the place: see here they come.
Since they themselves have tongues, mine shall be dumb.

div1.stage: Enter Andelocia with the wishing Hat on: Agripyna in his hand.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: What devil art thou that affrightest me thus,
Haling a Princess from her fathers court,
To spoil her in this savage wilderness?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
Indeed the devil and the pick-purse should always
fly together, (for they are sworn brothers:) but Madam
Covetousness, I am neither a devil as you call me, nor a Jeweller
as I call myself, no, nor a Juggler, yet ere you and I part,
we will have some legerdemain together: do you know me?

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: I am betrayed: this is the Cypriot.
Forgive me, it was not I that changed thy purse,
But Athelstane my father, send me home,
And here is thy purse again: here are thy Jewels,
And I in satisfaction of all wrongs.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
Talk not you of satisfaction, this is some recompense
that I have you, it is not the purse I regard: put it off, and
I will mince it as small as pie meat: the purse? hang the purse:
were that gon, I can make another, and another, and another,
Aye and another: it is not the purse I care for, but the purser: you,
Aye you. Is it not a shame that a kings daughter, a fair Lady,
a Lady not for Lords, but for Monarchs, should for gold sell
her love, and when she has her own asking, and that there
stands nothing between, then to cheat your sweet heart? O
fie, fie, a she cony-catcher? You must be dealt soundly with.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p:
Enjoin what pains thou wilt, and I will endure them,
so thou wilt send me to my fathers court.

sp.speaker: Ande.
sp.p:
Nay gods lid, ye are not gon so: set your heart at rest,
for I have set up my rest, that except you can run swifter
than a Heart, home you go not: what pains shall I lay upon
you? Let me see: I could serve you now but a slippery touch:
I could get a young King or two, or three of you, and then
send you home, and bid their grand-sire king nurse them: I
could pepper you, but I will not.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: O, do not violate my chastity.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
No, why I tell you I am not given to the flesh,
though I savour (in your nose) a little of the devil, I could run
away else, and starve you here.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: If I must die, doom me some easier death.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
Or transform you (because you love picking) into
a Squirrel, and make you pick out a poor living here among
the Nut trees: but I will not neither.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: What will my gentle Andelocia doe?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: O, now you come to your old bias of cogging.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: I pray thee Andelocia, let me go:
Send me to England, and by heaven I swear,
Thou from all kings on earth my love shalt bear.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Shall I in faith?

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: In faith, in faith thou shalt.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Here, god a mercy: now thou shalt not go.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: O God.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
Nay do you hear Lady? cry not ye are best: no nor
curse me not: if you think but a crabbed thought of me, the
spirit that carried you in mine arms through the air, will
tell me all: therefore set your Sunday face upon it. Since you will
love me, I will love you, I will marry you, and lie with you, and beget
little Jugglers: marry home you get not: England you will
say is yours: but Agripyne, love me, and I will make the
whole world thine.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: I care not for the world, thou murderest me,
Between my sorrow, and the scalding Sun
I faint, and quickly will my life be done,
My mouth is like a Furnace, and dry heat
Drinks up my blood. O God, my heart will burst,
I die, unless some moisture quench my thirst.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: 'sheart now I am worse than ever I was before:
For half the world I would not have her die.
Here is neither spring nor ditch, nor rain, nor dew,
Nor bread, nor drink: my lovely Agripyne,
Be comforted, see here are Apple trees.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Clime up for Gods sake, reach me some of them.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Look up, which of these Apples likes thee best?

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: This hath a withered face, it is some sweet fruit.
Not that, my sorrows are too sour already.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Come hither, here are Apples like gold.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: O, Aye for Gods sake, gather some of these.
Aye me, would God I were at home again.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Stand farther, least I chance to fall on thee.
sp.p:
O here be rare Apples, rare red-cheeked Apples, that cry come
kiss me: Apples, hold your peace, I will teach you to cry.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: O England, shall I never behold thee more?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
Agripyna, it is a most Sugared delicious taste in ones
mouth, but when it is down, it is as bitter as gall.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Yet gather some of them. O, that a Princess
Should pine for food: were I at home again,
I should disdain to stand thus and complain.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
Here is one Apple that grows highest, Agripyna, and I
could reach that, I will come down.

div1.stage: Hee stands fishing with his girdle for it.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: Make haste, for the hot Sun doth scald my cheeks.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
The sun kiss thee? hold, catch, put on my Hat, I
will have yonder highest Apple, though I die for it.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: I had not wont be Sun-burnt, wretched me.
O England, would I were again in thee.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: 'swounds Agripyna, stay, O I am undone,
Sweet Agripyna, if thou hearst my voice,
Take pity of me, and return again.
She flies like lightning: O she hears me not,
I wish myself into a wilderness,
And now I shall turn wild: here I shall famish,
Here die, here cursing die, here raving die,
And thus will wound my breast, and rent mine hair.
What hills of Flint are grown upon my brows?
O me, two forked horns, I am turned beast,
I have abused two blessings, wealth and knowledge,
Wealth in my purse, and knowledge in my Hat,
By which being born into the Courts of kings,
I might have seen the wondrous works of Jove,
Acquired Experience, Learning, Wisdom, Truth,
But I in wilderness tottered out my youth,
And therefore must turn wild: must be a beast,
An ugly beast: my body horns must bear,
Because my soul deformity doth wear.
Lives none within this wood? If none but I
Live here (thanks heaven) for here none else shall die.

div1.stage: He lies downe and sleepes vnder the tree: Enter Fortune, Vice, Vertue, the Priest: Satyres with Musicke, playing as they come in before Fortune. They play awhile.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: See where my new-turned devil has built his hell.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: Virtue, who conquers now? the fool is taken.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: O sleepy sin.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: Sweet tunes wake him again.

sp.speaker: Fortun.
sp.l: Vice sets too heavy on his drowsy soul,
Musics sweet concord cannot pierce his ear.
Sing and amongst your Songs, mix bitter scorn.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Those that tear Virtue, must by Vice be torn.
Virtue stand aside: the fool is caught,
Laugh to see him, laugh aloud to wake him,
Follies nets are wide, and neatly wrought,
Mock his horns, and laugh to see Vice take him.
Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, laugh, laugh in scorn,
Who is the fool? the fool, he wears a horn.
Virtue stand aside, mock him, mock him, mock him
Laugh aloud to see him, call him fool.
Error gave him suck, now sorrows rock him,
Send the riotous beast to madness school.
Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, laugh, laugh in scorn,
Who is the fool: the fool, he wears a horn.
Virtue stand aside: your school he hates.
Laugh aloud to see him, mock, mock, mock him.
Vanity and hell keep open gates,
He is in, and a new nurse (Despair) must rock him.
Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, laugh, laugh in scorn,
Fool, fool, fool, fool, fool, wear still the horn.

div1.stage: When they haue done singing, Vice and Vertue hold Apples out to him, Vice laughing, Vertue grieuing.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: O me, what hell is this? fiends, tempt me not.
Thou glorious devil hence. O now I see,
This fruit is thine, thou hast deformed me:
Idiot avoid, thy gifts I loath to taste.
Away: since I am entered madness School,
As good to be a beast, as be a fool.
Away, why tempt you me? some powerful grace
Come and redeem me from this hideous place.

sp.speaker: Fortun.
sp.l: To her hath Andelocia (all his life)
Sworn fealty, wouldst thou forsake her now?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Whose blessed tongue names Andelocia?

sp.speaker: Fortun.
sp.l: Hers, who (attended on by destinies)
Shortened thy Fathers life, and lengthens thine.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: O sacred Queen of chance, now shorten mine,
Else let thy deity take off this shame.

sp.speaker: Fortun.
sp.l: Woo her, it was she that set it on thy head.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: She laughs to see me metamorphosed.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Woo me, and I will take off this ugly scorn.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: Woo me, and I will clap on another horn.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: I am beset with anguish, shame and death.
O bid the Fates work fast, and stop my breath.

sp.speaker: Fortun.
sp.l: No Andelocia, thou must live to see
Worse torments (for thy follies) light on thee.
This golden tree, which did thine eyes entice,
Was planted here by Vice: lo, here stands Vice:
How often hast thou sued to win her grace?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Till now, I never did behold her face.

sp.speaker: Fortun.
sp.l: Thou didst behold her at thy fathers death,
When thou in scorn didst violate his will,
Thou didst behold her, when thy streched-out arm
Catched at the highest bough, the loftiest vice,
The fairest Apple, but the foulest price.
Thou didst behold her, when thy lickerish eye
Fed on the beauty of fair Agripyne,
Because thou hadst gold, thou thoughtest all women thine,
When lookest thou off from her? for they whose souls
Still revel in the nights of vanity,
On the fair cheeks of Vice still fix their eye.
Because her face doth shine, and all her bosom
Bears silver Moons, thou wast enamoured of her.
But hadst thou upward looked, and seen these shames,
Or viewed her round about, and in this glass
Seen Idiots faces, heads of devils and hell,
And read this ha, ha, he, this merry story,
Thou wouldst have loathed her: where, by loving her,
Thou bearst this face, and wearest this ugly head,
And if she once can bring thee to this place,
Loud sounds these ha, ha he, she will laugh apace.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: O, re-transform me to a glorious shape,
And I will learn how I may love to hate her.

sp.speaker: Fortun.
sp.p: I cannot re-transform thee, woo this woman.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: This woman? wretched is my state, when I,
To find out wisdom, to a fool must fly.

sp.speaker: Fortun.
sp.l: Fool, clear thine eyes, this is bright Arete,
This is poor Virtue, care not how the world
Doth crown her head, the world laughs her to scorn,
Yet Sibi sapit, Virtue knows her worth.
Run after her, she will give thee these and these
Crowns and Bay-garlands: (honours victories:)
Serve her, and she will fetch thee pay from heaven,
Or give thee some bright office in the stars.

sp.speaker: Ande.
sp.l: Immortal Arete, Virtue divine,
O smile on me, and I will still be thine.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Smile thou on me, and I will still be thine:
Though I am jealous of thy Apostasy,
I will entertain thee: here, come taste this tree,
Here is Physic for thy sick deformity.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: It is bitter: this fruit I shall never digest.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Try once again, the bitterness soon dies.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: Mines sweet, taste mine.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: But being down it is sour,
And mine being down has a delicious taste.
The path that leads to Virtues court is narrow,
Thorny and up a hill, a bitter journey,
But being gon through, you find all heavenly sweets,
The entrance is all flinty, but at the end,
To towers of pearl and crystal you ascend.

sp.speaker: Ande.
sp.l: O delicate, O sweet Ambrosian relish,
And see, my ugliness drops from my brows,
Thanks beauteous Arete: O had I now
My Hat and purse again, how I would shine,
And gild my soul with none but thoughts divine.

sp.speaker: Fortun.
sp.l: That shall be tried, take fruit from both these trees,
By help of them, win both thy purse and Hat,
I will instruct thee how, for on my wings
To England shalt thou ride; thy virtuous brother
Is (with that Shadow who attends on thee,)
In London, there I will set thee presently.
But if thou lose our favours once again,
To taste her sweets, those sweets must prove thy bane.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Vice, who shall now be crowned with victory?

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: She that triumphs at last, and that must I.

div1.stage: Enter Athelstane, Lincolne with Agripyne, Cyprus, Galloway, Cornewall, Chester, Longauile and Montrosse.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Lincolne, how settest thou her at liberty?

sp.speaker: Lincol.
sp.l: No other prison held her but your court,
There (in her chamber) hath she hid herself
These two days, only to shake off that fear,
Which her late violent rapture cast upon her.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: Where hath the beauteous Agripyna been?

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: In heaven or hell, in or without the world,
I know not which, for as I oft have seen
(When angry Thamesis hath curled her locks,)
A whirlwind come, and from her frizzled brows,
Snatch up a handful of those sweaty pearls,
That stood upon her forehead, which awhile,
Being by the boisterous wind hung in the air,
At length hath flung them down and raised a storm.
Even with such fury was I wherried up,
And by such force held prisoner in the clouds,
And thrown by such a tempest down again.

sp.speaker: Cornw.
sp.l: Some soul is damned in hell for this black deed.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: I have the purse safe, and anon your grace
Shall hear this wondrous history at full.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: Tell me, tormentor, shall fair Agripyne,
Without more difference be now christened mine?

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: My choice must be my Fathers fair consent.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Then shall thy choice end in this Cyprus prince.
Before the Sun shall six times more arise,
His royal marriage will we solemnise.
Proclaim this honoured match, come Agripyne,
I am glad thou art here, more glad the purse is mine.

div1.stage: As they are all going in: Enter Andelocia and Shaddowe, like Irish Coster-mongers, Agripyna, Longauyle, and Montrosse stay listening to them, the rest Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p:
Buy any Apples, fine Apples of Tamasco, fine
Tamasio pippins: peeps fine, buy Tamasco pippins.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Damasco apples? good my Lord Montrosse,
Call yonder fellows.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Sirrah Costermonger.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p:
Who calls? peeps of Tamasco, fine peeps: and that is the sweetest apple in the world, it is better than the Pome water,
or apple Iohn.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
By my trat Madam, it is reet Tamasco pippins,
look here else.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p:
I dare not say, as the Irishman my countrymen say,
taste the
goodness of the fruit: No faith it is
fairy teere mistress, by
Saint Patrickes hand it is teere Tamasco apple.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: The fairest fruit that ever I beheld,
Damasco apples, wherefore are they good?

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: What is your price of half a score of these?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Half a score, half a score? that is does many master.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: Aye, Aye, ten, half a score, that is five and five.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
Five and Five? By my trat and as Creeze save
me la, I cannot tell, what be the price of Five and Five, but it is
tree crown for one Pippin, that is the price if you take them.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: Aye fat, it is no less for Tamasco.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p:
Three crowns for one? what wondrous virtues
have they?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p:
O, it is fine Tamasco apple, and shall make you a
great deal wise, and make you no fool, and make fine memory.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
And make this face be more fair and amiable, and
make these eyes look always lovely, and make all the court
and country burn in desire to kiss the none sweet countenance.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Apples to make a Lady beautiful?
Madam that is excellent.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: These Irishmen,
Some say, are great dissemblers, and I fear,
These two the badge of their own country wear.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
By my trat, and by Saint Patrickes hand, and
as Creez save me la, it is no dissembler: the Irish man now and
then cut the
countryman's throat, but yet in faith he love the
countryman, it is no dissembler: this fine Tamasco apple can
make the sweet countenance, but I can take no less but three
crowns for one, I wear out my naked legs and my foots,
and my toes, and run hither and thither to Tamasco for them.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.l: As Creez save me la, he speaks true: Peeps fine,

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: I will try what power lies in Damasco fruit.
Here are ten crowns for three, So fare you well.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Lord Longauyle, buy some.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: I buy? not I:
Hang them, they are toys, come Madam, let us go.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Saint Patricke and Saint Peter, and all the holy
Angels look upon that face and make it fair.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, she is sped, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Peace, Shaddow, buy any pippins, buy.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Peeps fine, fine Tamasco apples.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Came not Lord Longauyle to buy some fruit?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
No fat, master, here came no Lords nor Ladies,
but the none sweet self.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: It is well, say nothing, here is six crowns for two:
You say the virtues are to make one strong.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Yes fat and make sweet countenance, and strong too.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: It is excellent, here: farewell, if these prove,
I will conquer men by strength, women by love.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, why this is rare.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.l: Peace, master, here comes another fool.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Peeps fine, buy any peeps of Tamasco?

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: Did not the Lord Montrosse return to you?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: No fat, sweet master, no Lord did turn to us:
Peeps fine.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: I am glad of it: here are nine crowns for thee:
What are the virtues besides making fair?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: O, it will make thee wondrous wise.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p:
And thou shall be no more a fool, but sweet face
and wise.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: It is rare, farewell, I never yet durst woo.
None loves me: now I will try what these can do.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha, So, this is admirable, Shaddow, here
end my torments in Saint Patrickes Purgatory, but thine
shall continue longer.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: Did I not clap on a good false Irish face?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: It became thee rarely.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p:
Yet that is lamentable, that a false face should become
any man.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
Thou art a gull, it is all the fashion now, which
fashion because we will keep, step thou abroad, let not the world
want fools: whilst thou art commencing thy knavery there,
I will proceed Doctor Dodipoll here: that done, thou Shaddow
and I will fat ourselves to behold the transformation of these
fools: go fly.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p:
I fear nothing, but that whilst we strive to make
others fools, we shall wear the Coxcombs ourselves, Pips
fine etcetera.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: 'sheart, here is my brother whom I have abused:
His presence makes me blush, it strikes me dead,
To think how I am metamorphosed.
fine pippins of Tamasco etcetera.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: For shame cast off this Mask.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Wilt thou buy any pips?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Mock me no longer
With idle apparitions: many a land
Have I with weary feet and a sick soul
Measured, to find thee; and when thou art found,
My greatest grief is, that thou art not lost:
Yet lost thou art, thy fame, thy wealth are lost,
Thy wits are lost, and thou hast in their stead,
With shame and cares, and misery crowned thy head.
That Shaddow that pursues thee, filled mine ears
With sad relation of thy wretchedness,
Where is the purse, and where my wishing Hat?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
Where? and where? are you created Constable, you
stand so much upon Interrogatories? the purse is gone, let that
fret you, and the Hat is gone, let that mad you: I run thus
through all trades to overtake them, if you will be quiet, follow
me, and help, if not, fly from me, and hang yourself: wilt
thou buy any pippins?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: O, how I grieve, to see him thus transformed?
Yet from the circles of my jealous eyes,
He shall not start, till he have repossessed
Those virtuous Jewels, which found once again,
More cause they never shall give me to complain.
Their worth shall be consumed in murdering flames,
And end my grief, his riot, and our shames.

div1.stage: Enter Athelstane, Agripyne, Montrosse and Longauyle with hornes, Lincolne and Cornwall.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: In spite of sorcery try once again,
Try once more in contempt of all damned spells.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Your majesty fights with no mortal power.
Shame and not conquest, hangs upon his strife.
O, touch me not, you add but pain to pain,
The more you cut, the more they grow again.

sp.speaker: Lincol.
sp.l: Is there no art to conjure down this scorn?
I never knew Physic yet against the horn.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: See, prince of Cyprus, thy fair Agripyne
Hath turned her beauty to deformity.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: Then I defy thee, Love, vain hopes, adieu,
You have mocked me long; in scorn I will now mock you.
I came to see how the Lord Longauyle
Was turned into a monster, and I find
An object, which both strikes me dumb and blind.
Tomorrow should have been our marriage morn,
But now my bride is shame, thy bridegroom scorn.
O tell me yet, is there no Art, no charms,
No desperate Physic for this desperate wound?

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: All means are tried, but no means can be found.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: Then England, farewell: hapless maid, thy stars,
Through spiteful influence set our hearts at wars.
I am enforced to leave thee, and resign
My love to grief.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: All grief to Agripyne.

sp.speaker: Cypr.
sp.l: Adieu, I would say more, had I a tongue
Able to help his master: mighty king,
I humbly take my leave, to Cyprus I,
My fathers Son, must all such shame defy.

sp.speaker: Orle.
sp.l: So doth not Orleans, I defy all those,
That love not Agripyne, and him defy,
That dares but love her half so well as I.
O pardon me, I have in sorrows Jail,
Been long tormented, long this mangled bosom
Hath bled, and never durst expose her wounds,
Till now, till now, when at thy beauteous feet,
I offer love and life, O cast an eye
Of mercy on me, this deformed face
Cannot affright my soul from loving thee.

sp.speaker: Agri.
sp.l: Talk not of love, good Orleans, but of hate.

sp.speaker: Orle.
sp.l: What sentence will my love pronounce on me?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Will Orleans then be mad? O gentle friend.

sp.speaker: Orle.
sp.l: O gentle, gentle friend, I am not mad:
He is mad, whose eyes on painted cheeks do dote,
O Galloway; such read beauties book by rote.
He is mad, that pines for want of a gay flower,
Which fades when grief doth blast, or sickness lower,
Which heat doth wither, and white ages frost
Nips dead: such fairness, when it is found, it is lost,
I am not mad, for loving Agripyne,
My love looks on her eyes, with eyes divine,
I dote on the rich brightness of her mind,
That sacred beauty strikes all other blind,
O make me happy then, since my desires
Are set a burning by loves purest fires.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: So thou wilt bear her far from England sight,
Enjoy thy wishes.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Lock me in some cave,
Where staring wonders eye shall not be guilty
To my abhorred looks, and I will die
To thee, as full of love as misery.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: I am amazed and mad, some speckled soul
Lies pawned for this in Hell, without redemption,
Some fiend deludes us all.

sp.speaker: Cornw.
sp.l: O unjust Fates,
Why do you hide from us this mystery?

sp.speaker: Lincol.
sp.l: My Lord Montrosse, how long have your brows worn
This fashion? these two feather-springs of horn?

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: An Irish kern sold me Damasco apples,
Some two hours since, and (like a credulous fool)
He swearing to me that they had this power,
To make me strong in body, rich in mind,
I did believe his words, tasted his fruit,
And since have been attired in this disguise.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: I fear that villain hath beguiled me too.

sp.speaker: Cornw.
sp.l: Nay before God he has not cozened you,
You have it soundly.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: Me he made believe,
One apple of Damasco would inspire
My thoughts with wisdom, and upon my cheeks
Would cast such beauty, that each Ladies eye,
Which looked on me, should love me presently.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Desire to look more fair, makes me more foul,
Those apples did entice my wandering eye,
To be enamoured of deformity.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: This proves that true, which oft I have heard in schools,
Those that would seem most wise, do turn most fools.

sp.speaker: Lincol.
sp.l: Here is your best hope, none needs to hide his face,
For horned foreheads swarm in every place.

div1.stage: Enter Chester bringing Andelocia like a French Doctor.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Now Chester, what Physicians hast thou found?

sp.speaker: Chest.
sp.l: Many, my liege, but none that have true skill
To tame such wild diseases: yet here is one,
A Doctor and a Frenchman, whom report
Of Agripynes grief hath drawn to court.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Cure her, and Englands treasury shall stand,
As free for thee to use, as rain from heaven.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Cure me, and to thy Coffers I will send,
More gold from Scotland than thy life can spend.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: Cure Longauile, and all his wealth is thine.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
He Monsieur Long-villain gra thank you: Gra
thank your majesty a great deal artely by my trat: where be
this Madam Princess that be so mush torment? O Jesu: one,
two an three, four and five, seez horn? Ha, ha, ha, pardon moi pray with
all mine art, for by my trat, me can no point shose but laugh,
Ha, ha, ha, to mark how like tree bul-beggera, they stand.
O, by my trat and fat, the diuela be whoreson, scurvy, paltry,
ill favour knave to mock de Madam, and gentleman so:
Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lincol.
sp.p: This Doctor comes to mock your majesty.

sp.speaker: Ande.
sp.p:
No by my trat la, but me love much much merriment:
Come Madam, prea-artely stand still, and let me
feel you: this horn, O it is pretty horn, this be facile, easy for
pull de vey, but Madam this O be grand, grand horn, difficult,
and very deep, it is perilous, a grand Laroone. But Madam,
pray be patient, we shall take it off well.

sp.speaker: Athe.
sp.l: Thrice have we pared them off, but with fresh pain,
In compass of a thought they rise again.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
It is true, it is no easy matter, to pull horn off, it is
easy for pull on, but hard for pull off, some horn be so good
fellow, he will still inhabit in the man's pate, but it is all one
for tat, I shall snap away all this: Madam trust this down
into your little belly.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Father, I am in fear to taste his physic.
First let him work experiments on those.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: I will sauce you for your infidelity.
In no place can I spy my wishing Hat.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: Thou learned Frenchman, try thy skill on me,
More ugly than I am, I cannot be.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Cure me, and Montrosse wealth shall all be thine.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
It is all one for that:
shall do presently; Madam,
pray mark me: Monsieur, shamp this in your two shaps, so,
now Monsieur Long-villain; this so: now this, fear noting,
it is excellent medicine: so, now cram this into your guts, and
belly: So, now snap away this whoreson four diuela; Ha,
ha, Is no point good?

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: This is most strange.
Was it painful Longauyle?

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: Ease took them off, and there remains no pain.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: O try thy sacred Physic on me.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
No by my trat, it is no possible, it is no possible, all the
matter, all the ting, all the substance, all the medicine, be among
his and his belly: it is no possible, till me prepare more.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Prepare it then, and thou shalt have more gold
From Englands Coffers, than thy life can waste.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
I mush buy many costly tings that grow in Arabia,
in Asia, and America, by my trat it is no possible, till another
time, no point.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: There is nothing in the world, but may for gold
Be bought in England, hold your lap I will rain
A shower of Angels.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
Fie, fie, fie, fie, you no credit le dockature? Ha, but
well, it is all one for that: it is no matter for gold: Well, well, well, well,
well, me have some more, pray say noting, shall be presently
prepare for your horns.
sp.l: She has my purse, and yonder lies my Hat,
Work brains, and once more make me fortunate.
sp.p:
Well, well, well, well, be patient Madam, presently, presently,
be patient, me have two, tree, four and five medicines for
the horn: presently Madam, stand you there,
pray with all mine
art, stand you all there: and say noting, so: nor look noting this
vey: so, presently, presently Madam, snip this horn off with
de rushes and another ting by and by, by and by, by and by, pray
look none this vey, and say noting.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Let no man speak, or look, upon his life.
Doctor, none here shall rob thee of thy skill.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
So, take this hand: wink now pray artely with
your two eyes: why so.
Would I were with my brother Ampedo.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: Help, Father, help, I am hurried hence perforce.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Draw weapons, where is the princess, follow him,
Stay the French Doctor, stay the Doctor there.

div1.stage: Cornwall and some other run out, and enter presently.

sp.speaker: Cornw.
sp.l: Stay him, 'sheart who dare stay him? it is the devil
In likeness of a Frenchman, of a Doctor.
Look how a rascal Kite having swept up
A Chicken in his claws, so flies this hell-hound
In the air with Agripyne in his arms.

sp.speaker: Orle.
sp.l: Mount every man upon his swiftest horse.
Fly several ways, he cannot bear her far.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: These paths we will beat.

sp.speaker: Lincol.
sp.l: And this way shall be mine.

sp.speaker: Cornw.
sp.l: This way, my Liege, I will ride.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: And this way I:
No matter which way, to seek misery.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: I can ride no way, to outrun my shame.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Yes, Longauile, let us gallop after too,
Doubtless this Doctor was that Irish devil,
That cozened us, the medicine which he gave us,
Tasted like his Damasco villainy.
To horse, to horse, if we can catch this fiend,
Our forked shame shall in his heart blood end.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: O how this mads me, that all tongues in scorn,
Which way so ere I ride, cry, Ware the horn.

div1.stage: Enter Andelocia, with Agripyne, Ampedo and Shaddow.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.l: O gentle Andelocia pity me,
Take off this infamy, or take my life.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
Your life? you think then that I am a true Doctor
indeed, that tie up my living in the knots of winding
sheets: your life? no, keep your life, but deliver your purse:
you know the thiefs salutation, Stand and deliver. So, this is
mine, and these yours: I will teach you to live by the sweat of
other men's brows.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: And to strive to be fairer than God made her.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
Right, Shaddow: therefore vanish, you have made
me turn Juggler, and cry hey-passe, but your horns shall not
repass.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: O gentle Andelocia.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Andelocia is a Nettle: if you touch him gently, he will sting you.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: Or a rose, if you pull his sweet stalk, he will prick you.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
Therefore not a word, go, trudge to your Father:
sigh not for your purse, money may be got by you, as well as
by the little Welshwoman in Cyprus, that had but one horn
in her head, you have
two; and perhaps you shall cast both: as
you use me, mark those words well, as you use me, nay,
you are best fly, I will not endure one word more. Yet stay too, because
you entreat me so gently, and that I will make some amends
to your Father, although I care not for any King in
Christendom, yet hold you, take this Apple, eat it as you
go to court, and your horns shall play the cowards and fall
from you.

sp.speaker: Agrip.
sp.p: O gentle Andelocia.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: Nay away, not a word.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, etcetera. Ware horns.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p: Why dost thou laugh, Shaddow?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p: To see what a horn plague follows covetousness and pride.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Brother, what mysteries lie in all this?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
Tricks, Ampedo, tricks, devices, and mad Hieroglyphics,
mirth, mirth, and melody. O, there is more music
in this, than all the Gammoth ares, and Sol fa Res, in
the world; here is the purse, and here is
the Hat: because you
shall be sure I will not start, wear you this, you know his virtue;
if danger beset you, fly and away: A sort of broken-shinned
limping legged Jades run hobbling to seek us: Shaddow,
we will for all this have one fit of mirth more, to make us laugh
and be fat.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p:
And when we are fat, master, we will do
as all gluttons
do, laugh and lie down.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
Hie thee to my chamber, make ready my richest
attire, I will to Court presently.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p:
I will go to Court in this attire, for apparel is but
the shaddow of a man, but shaddow is the substance of his apparel.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Away, away, and meet me presently.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: I had more need to cry, away to thee.
Away, away with this wild lunacy,
Away with riots.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.p:
Away with your purity, brother, you are an Ass,
why doth this purse spit out gold but to be spent? why lives a
man in this world, to dwell in the Suburbs of it, as you do?
Away foreign simplicity, away: are not eyes made to see fair
Ladies? hearts to love them? tongues to court them, and
hands
to feel them? Out you Stock, you stone, you logs end: Are
not legs made to dance, and shall mine limp up and down
the world after your cloth-stocking-heels? you have the Hat,
keep it, anon I will visit your virtuous countenance again, adieu,
pleasure is my sweet mistress, I wear her love in my
Hat, and her soul in my heart: I have sworn to be merry,
and in spite of Fortune and the black-browed destinies, I will
never be sad.

sp.speaker: Amped.
sp.l: Go, fool, in spite of mirth, thou shalt be sad.
I will bury half thy pleasures in a grave
Of hungry flames, this fire I did ordain
To burn both purse and Hat: as this doth perish,
So shall the other: count what good and bad
They both have wrought, the good is to the ill,
As a small Pebble to a mighty hill.
Thy glory and thy mischiefs here shall burn,
Good gifts abused to man's confusion turn.

div1.stage: Enter Longauile, and Montrosse with Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: This is his brother; Soldiers, bind his arms.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Bind arms and legs, and hale the fiend a way.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Uncivil: wherefore must I taste your spite?

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: Art thou not one of Fortunatus sons?

sp.speaker: Amped.
sp.l: I am, but he did never do you wrong.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: The devil thy brother has, villain, look here.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Where is the beauteous purse and wishing Hat?

sp.speaker: Amped.
sp.l: My brother Andelocia has the purse,
This way he will come anon to pass to court,
Alas, that sin should make men's hearts so bold,
To kill their souls for the base thirst of gold.
The wishing Hat is burnt.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Burnt? Soldiers bind him.
Tortures shall wring both hat and purse from you,
Villain, I will be revenged for that base scorn,
Thy hell-hound brother clapped upon my head.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: And so will Longauyle.
Away with him.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Drag him to yonder tower, there shackle him,
And in a pair of Stocks, lock up his heels,
And bid your wishing Cap deliver you.
Give us the purse and Hat, we will set thee free,
Else rot to death and starve.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: O tyranny, you need not scorn the badge which you did bear:
Beasts would you be, though horns you did not wear.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Drag hence the cur: come noble Longauyle,
One is sure, and were the other fiend as fast,
Their pride should cost their lives: their purse and Hat
Shall be both ours, we will share them equally.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: That will be some amends for arming me.

div1.stage: Enter Andelocia and Shaddow after him.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Peace, Longauyle, yonder the gallant comes.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: You are well encountered.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Thanks, Lord Longauyle.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: The king expects your presence at the court.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: And thither am I going.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.l: Pips fine, fine apples of Tamasco, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Wert thou that Irishman that cozened us?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.l: Pips fine, ha, ha, ha, no not I: not Shaddow.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Were not your Apples delicate and rare?

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: The worst that ere you sold; Sirs, bind him fast.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: What, will you murder me? help, help, some help.

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.l: Help, help, help.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Follow that Dog, and stop his balling throat.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Villains, what means this barbarous treachery?

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: We mean to be revenged for our disgrace.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: And stop the golden current of thy waste.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Murder, they murder me, O call for help.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Thy voice is spent in vain, come, come, this purse,
This well-spring of your prodigality.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Are you appointed by the king to this?

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: No, no, rise, spurn him up: know you who is this?

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: My brother Ampedo? Alas, what fate
Hath made thy virtues so infortunate?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Thy riot and the wrong of these two Lords,
Who (causeless) thus do starve me in this prison.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: Strive not you are best, villains, lift in his legs.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Traitors to honour, what do you intend?

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: That riot shall in wretchedness have end.
Question thy brother with what cost he is fed,
And so assure thou shalt be banqueted.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: In want, in misery, in woe and care,
Poor Ampedo his fill hath surfeited:
My want is famine, bolts my misery,
My care and woe should be thy portion.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Give me that portion, for I have a heart
Shall spend it freely, and make bankrupt
The proudest woe that ever wet man's eye.
Care with a mischief? wherefore should I care?
Have I rid side by side by mighty kings,
Yet be thus bridled now? I will tear these fetters.
Murder, cry murder, Ampedo, aloud.
To bear this scorn our Fortunes are too proud.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: O folly, thou hast power to make flesh glad,
When the rich soul in wretchedness is clad.

sp.speaker: Ande.
sp.l: Peace, fool, am not I Fortunes minion?
These bands are but one wrinkle of her frown,
This is her Evening mask, her next morns eye
Shall over-shine the Sun in majesty.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: But this sad night will make an end of me.
Brother, farewell, grief, famine, sorrow, want,
Have made an end of wretched Ampedo.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Where is the wishing Hat?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Consumed in fire.

sp.speaker: Ande.
sp.l: Accursed be those hands that did destroy it,
That would redeem us, did we now enjoy it.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.l: Wanton farewell, I faint, deaths frozen hand
Congeals life's little River in my breast.
No man before his end is truly blessed.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: O miserable, miserable soul.
Thus a foul life makes death to look more foul.

div1.stage: Enter Longauyle and Montrosse with a halter.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: Thus shall this golden purse divided be,
One day for you, another day for me.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Of days anon, say, what determine you,
Shall they have liberty, or shall they die?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Die sure: and see, I think the elder is dead.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Aye, murderers, he is dead. O sacred wisdom,
Had Fortunatus been enamoured
Of thy celestial beauty, his two sons
Had shined like two bright Suns.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: Pull hard, Montrosse.

sp.speaker: Andel.
sp.l: Come you to strangle me? are you the hangman?
Hell-hounds ye are damned for this impiety.
Fortune, forgive me, I deserve thy hate,
Myself have made myself a reprobate:
Virtue, forgive me, for I have transgressed
Against thy laws, my vows are quite forgot,
And therefore shame is fallen to my sins lot.
Riches and knowledge are two gifts divine.
They that abuse them both as I have done,
To shame, to beggary, to hell must run.
O conscience hold thy sting, cease to afflict me.
Be quick, tormentors, I desire to die.
No death is equal to my misery.
Cyprus, vain world, and Vanity farewell.
Who builds his heaven on earth, is sure of hell.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: he is dead: in some deep vault let us throw their bodies.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: First let us see the purse, Lord Longauyle.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: Here it is, by this we will fill this tower with gold.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Frenchman, this purse is counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: Thou liest.
Scot, thou hast cozened me, give me the right,
Else shall thy bosom be my weapons grave.

sp.speaker: Montr.
sp.l: Villain, thou shalt not rob me of my due.

div1.stage: They fight: Enter Athelstane, Agripyna, Orleans, Galloway, Cornewall, Chester, Lincolne, and Shaddow with weapons at one dore: Fortune, Vice, and their attendants at another dore.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Lay hands upon the murderers, strike them down.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: Surrender up this purse, for this is mine.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Are these two devils, or some powers divine?

sp.speaker: Shad.
sp.p:
O see, see, O my two masters, poor Shaddowes
substances; what shall I do? whose body shall Shaddow now
follow?

sp.speaker: Fortun.
sp.l: Peace, Idiot, thou shalt find rich heaps of fools,
That will be proud to entertain a Shaddow.
I charm thy babbling lips from troubling me.
You need not hold them, see, I smite them down
Lower than hell: base souls, sink to your heaven.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: I do arrest you both my prisoners.

sp.speaker: Fortun.
sp.l: Stand not amazed, you gods of earth, at this,
She that arresteth these two fools is Vice,
They have broke Virtues laws, Vice is her sergeant,
Her Jailer and her executioner.
Look on those Cypriots, Fortunatus sons,
They and their Father were my minions,
My name is Fortune.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: O dread deity.

sp.speaker: Fortun.
sp.l: Kneel not to me: if Fortune list to frown,
You need not fall down, for she will spurn you down.
Arise, but fools, on you I will triumph thus.
What have you gained by being covetous?
This prodigal purse did Fortunes bounteous hand
Bestow on them, their riots made them poor,
And set these marks of miserable death,
On all their pride, the famine of base gold
Hath made your souls to murders hands be sold,
Only to be called rich. But Idiots see
The virtues to be fled, Fortune hath caused it so,
Those that will all devour, must all forgo.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Most sacred Goddess.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: Peace, you flatterer.
Thy tongue but heaps more vengeance on thy head.
Fortune is angry with thee, in thee burns
A greedy covetous fire; in Agripyne
Pride like a Monarch revels, and those sins
Have lead you blind-fold to your former shames,
But Virtue pardoned you, and so doth Fortune.

sp.speaker: Athelst. & Agrip.
sp.l: All thanks to both your sacred deities.

sp.speaker: Fortun.
sp.l: As for these Metal-eaters, these base thieves,
Who rather than they would be counted poor,
Will dig through hell for gold, you were forgiven
By Virtues general pardon; her broad seal
Gave you your lives, when she took off your horns.
Yet having scarce one foot out of the Jail,
You tempt damnation by more desperate means,
You both are mortal, and your pains shall ring
Through both your ears, to terrify your souls,
As please the Judgment of this mortal king.

sp.speaker: Athelst.
sp.l: Fair Empress of the world, since you resign
Your power to me, this sentence shall be mine,
Thou shalt be tortured on a wheel to death,
Thou with wild horses shalt be quartered.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: Ha, ha, weak Judge, weak judgment, I reverse
That sentence, for they are my prisoners,
Embalm the bodies of those Cypriots,
And honour them with princely burial,
For those do as you please, but for these two,
I kiss you both, I love you, ye are my minions.
Untie their bands, Vice doth reprieve you both,
I set you free.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Thanks, gracious deity.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: Be gon, but you in liberty shall find
More bondage than in chains, fools, get you hence,
Both wander with tormented conscience.

sp.speaker: Longa.
sp.l: O horrid Judgment, that is the hell indeed.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: Come, come, our death never ends if conscience bleed.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: O miserable, miserable men.

sp.speaker: Fortune.
sp.l: Fortune triumphs at this, yet to appear,
All like myself, that which from those I took,
King Athelstane I will bestow on thee,
And in it the old virtue I infuse:
But, king, take heed how thou my gifts dost use.
England shall never be poor, if England strive,
Rather by virtue, than by wealth to thrive.

div1.stage: Enter Vertue, crownd: Nymphes and kings attendin on her, crownd with Oliue branches and lawrels, musicke sounding.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: Virtue? alas good soul, she hides her head.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: What envious tongue said, Virtue hides her head?

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: She that will drive thee into banishment.

sp.speaker: Fortun.
sp.l: She that hath conquered thee; how darest thou come,
Thus tricked in gaudy Feathers, and thus guarded,
Which crowned kings and Muses, when thy foe
Hath trod thus on thee, and now triumphs so?
Where is virtuous Ampedo? See, he is her slave,
For following thee this recompense they have.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Is Ampedo her slave? why that is my glory.
The Idiots cap I once wore on my head,
Did figure him, those that (like him) do muffle
Virtue in clouds, and care not how she shine,
I will make their glory like to his decline:
He made no use of me, but like a miser,
Locked up his wealth in rusty bars of sloth:
His face was beautiful, but wore a mask,
And in the worlds eyes seemed a Blackamoor.
So perish they that so keep virtue poor.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: Thou art a fool to strive, I am more strong,
And greater than thyself, then Virtue fly,
And hide thy face, yield me the victory.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Is Vice higher than Virtue? that is my glory,
The higher that thou art, thou art more horrid,
The world will love me for my comeliness.

sp.speaker: Fortu.
sp.l: Thine own self loves thyself: why on the heads
Of Agripyne, Montrosse and Longauyle,
(English, Scot, French) did Vice clap ugly horns,
But to approve that English, French and Scot,
And all the world else, kneel and honour Vice,
But in no Country, Virtue is of price?

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Yes, in all Countries Virtue is of price,
In every kingdom some diviner breast
Is more enamoured of me than the rest.
Have English, Scot, and French bowed knees to thee?
Why that is my glory too, for by their shame,
Men will abhor thee and adore my name.
Fortune, thou art too weak, Vice thou art a fool,
To fight with me, I suffered you awhile,
To eclipse my brightness, but I now will shine,
And make you swear your beauty is base to mine.

sp.speaker: Fortun.
sp.l: Thou art too insolent, see here is a court
Of mortal Judges, let us by them be tried,
Which of us three shall most be deified.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: I am content.

sp.speaker: Fortun.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: So am not I.
My Judge shall be your sacred deity.

sp.speaker: Vice.
sp.l: O miserable me, I am undone.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: O stop the horrid monster.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Let her run.
Fortune, who conquers now?

sp.speaker: Fortun.
sp.l: Virtue, I see,
Thou wilt triumph both over her and me.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Empress of heaven and earth.

sp.speaker: Fortun.
sp.l: Why do you mock me?
Kneel not to me, to her transfer your eyes,
There sits the Queen of Chance, I bend my knees,
Lower than yours: dread goddess, it is most meet,
That Fortune fall down at thy conquering feet.
Thou sacred Empress that commandest the Fates,
Forgive what I have to thy handmaid done,
And at thy Chariot wheels Fortune shall run,
And be thy captive and to thee resign
All powers which heavens large Patent have made mine.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Fortune thou art vanquished: sacred deity,
O now pronounce who wins the victory,
And yet that sentence needs not, since alone,
Your virtuous presence Vice hath overthrown,
Yet to confirm the conquest on your side,
Look but on Fortunatus and his sons
Of all the wealth those gallants did possess,
Only poor Shaddow is left comfortless,
Their glory is faded and their golden pride.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Only poor Shadow tells how poor they died.

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: All that they had, or mortal men can have,
Sends only but a Shaddow from the grave.
Virtue alone lives still, and lives in you,
I am a counterfeit. you are the true,
I am a Shaddow, at your feet I fall,
Begging for these, and these, myself and all.
All these that thus do kneel before your eyes,
Are shaddowes like myself, dread Nymph it lies
In you to make us substances. O do it,
Virtue I am sure you love, she woes you to it.
I read a verdict in your Sun-like eyes,
And this it is: Virtue the victory.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: All loudly cry, Virtue the victory,

sp.speaker: Vert.
sp.l: Virtue the victory: for joy of this,
Those self same hymns which you to Fortune sung
Let them be now in Virtues honour rung.
Virtue smiles: cry holiday,
Dimples on her cheeks do dwell,
Virtue frowns, cry welladay,
Her love is Heaven, her hate is Hell.
Since heaven and hell obey her power,
Tremble when her eyes do lower.
Since heaven and hell her power obey,
Where she smiles, cry holiday,
Holiday with joy we cry,
And bend, and bend, and merrily,
Sing hymns to virtues deity:
Sing hymns to Virtues deity.

div1.stage: As they all offer to goe in, Enter the two old men.

sp.l: Nay stay, poor pilgrims, when I entered first
The circle of this bright celestial Sphere,
I wept for joy, now I could weep for fear.
I fear we all like mortal men shall prove,
Weak (not in love) but in expressing love.
Let everyone beg once more on his knee,
One pardon for himself, and one for me,
For I enticed you hither: O dear Goddess,
Breathe life in our numbed spirits with one smile,
And from this cold earth, we with lively souls
Shall rise like men (new-born) and make heaven sound
With Hymns sung to thy name, and prayers that we
May once a year so oft enjoy this sight,
Till these young boys change their curled locks to white,
And when gray-winged Age sits on their heads,
That so their children may supply their Steads,
And that heavens great Arithmetician,
(Who in Scales of Number weighs the world)
May still to forty two, and one year more,
And still add one to one, that went before,
And multiply four tens by many a ten:
To this I cry Amen.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Amen, Amen.
Good night (dear mistress) those that wish thee harm,
Thus let them stoop under destructions arm.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Amen, Amen, Amen.
